Egg Drop Soup

Jump to Recipe

If you're looking for a quick, comforting, and nourishing dish that embodies the essence of traditional Asian cuisine, look no further than Egg Drop Soup. This delightful recipe is not only simple to prepare but also features a warm, savory chicken broth that serves as the perfect canvas for silky ribbons of eggs and fresh green onions. Ideal for a cozy dinner or a light appetizer, Egg Drop Soup brings together a handful of wholesome ingredients like chicken broth, eggs, and soy sauce, making it a staple in many households. With just a few easy steps, you can whip up this classic dish that will impress your family and friends alike. Whether you’re craving a bowl on a rainy day or want to serve it alongside your favorite stir-fry, this Egg Drop Soup recipe is bound to become a go-to in your kitchen. So grab your ingredients and let’s dive into making this deliciously comforting soup!

Ingredients

chicken broth

Choose a low-sodium chicken broth if you're watching your salt intake, or make your own from scratch using chicken bones and vegetables for a fresher flavor. You can substitute vegetable broth for a vegetarian version.

cornstarch

Cornstarch is a great thickener; mix it with cold water before adding to hot liquids to avoid clumping. If you don't have cornstarch, you can use arrowroot powder or tapioca starch as a substitute.

water

Use filtered water for the best flavor. The water is used here to dissolve the cornstarch; ensure it's cold to help prevent lumps.

eggs

Use fresh eggs for the best flavor and texture. If you're looking for a lower-calorie option, you can substitute one whole egg with two egg whites.

green onions

Green onions can be substituted with chives or shallots for a different flavor profile. Use both white and green parts for added color and taste.

soy sauce

For a gluten-free version, substitute with tamari or coconut aminos. If you prefer a less salty flavor, opt for low-sodium soy sauce.

salt

Add salt gradually while tasting to avoid oversalting. You can also use sea salt or kosher salt for a different flavor.

pepper

Freshly cracked black pepper will give you a bolder flavor compared to pre-ground. For a twist, consider adding white pepper for a more subtle heat.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Simmer the Chicken Broth

    In a medium pot, bring the chicken broth to a gentle simmer over medium heat. This step is crucial as it forms the base of your soup. Make sure not to boil it vigorously, as that can affect the texture of the soup.

  • Step 2: Prepare the Cornstarch Slurry

    In a small bowl, mix the cornstarch with 2 tablespoons of water until smooth. This slurry will help thicken your soup. Make sure there are no lumps, as they can create a grainy texture in the final dish.

  • Step 3: Thicken the Broth

    Add the cornstarch mixture to the simmering broth and stir until it thickens slightly. Stir continuously to avoid lumps from forming and maintain a smooth consistency.

  • Step 4: Beat the Eggs

    Beat the eggs in a separate bowl until fully incorporated. This will help ensure that the eggs mix well into the soup, creating those lovely ribbons.

  • Step 5: Create Egg Ribbons

    Slowly pour the beaten eggs into the soup while stirring gently to create thin ribbons of egg. Pour the eggs in a thin stream for even distribution. This is where you'll see the beautiful texture of egg ribbons form.

  • Step 6: Add Seasonings

    Stir in green onions, soy sauce, salt, and pepper to taste. This is where you can customize your soup. Be cautious with the salt, as the soy sauce is already salty; taste before adding more.

  • Step 7: Final Cook and Serve

    Let it cook for another minute, then remove from heat and serve hot. This short cooking time allows the green onions to retain their crunch while infusing the soup with flavor.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the best way to prepare ingredients for Egg Drop Soup?

Start by measuring out your ingredients before you begin cooking. For this recipe, slice the green onions and beat the eggs in a separate bowl. This will make the cooking process smoother and help you stay organized.

How do I know when the chicken broth is at a gentle simmer?

A gentle simmer is when small bubbles are forming on the surface but the broth isn't boiling vigorously. Look for small bubbles rising but not a rolling boil. This usually happens at medium heat.

Why do I need to mix cornstarch with water before adding it to the broth?

Mixing cornstarch with water creates a slurry that prevents clumping when added to the hot broth. This helps thicken the soup evenly without lumps.

How can I create thin ribbons of egg in the soup?

To create thin ribbons of egg, pour the beaten eggs slowly into the soup while stirring gently with a fork or whisk. This motion helps the eggs cook quickly and form delicate strands.

What if I don’t have green onions? Can I substitute them?

If you don't have green onions, you can use finely chopped regular onions or shallots for a different flavor. Fresh parsley or chives can also be a nice alternative.

How do I safely handle raw eggs?

Always wash your hands and any surfaces that come into contact with raw eggs to prevent contamination. Use clean utensils, and be sure to cook the eggs thoroughly to eliminate any risk.

Can I adjust the flavor of the soup?

Absolutely! Feel free to add more soy sauce for a saltier flavor or additional spices like garlic powder or ginger for extra warmth. Just remember to adjust the salt accordingly.

What should I serve with Egg Drop Soup?

Egg Drop Soup can be enjoyed on its own or paired with a side of steamed rice or fried rice. It also complements dishes like dumplings or spring rolls.

How can I store leftover soup?

Let the soup cool to room temperature, then transfer it to an airtight container. It can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Reheat gently on the stove before serving.

How can I build confidence in the kitchen?

Start with simple recipes like this one, follow the steps carefully, and don't be afraid to experiment. The more you practice, the more comfortable you'll become. Remember, cooking is about learning and having fun!

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This Egg Drop Soup can be made gluten-free by using tamari instead of soy sauce and ensuring that the chicken broth is gluten-free. For a vegetarian option, substitute chicken broth with vegetable broth and omit soy sauce or use a gluten-free alternative. The recipe is inherently low in calories and can be a light option for those watching their intake.

Pairings

Egg Drop Soup pairs beautifully with light proteins such as steamed dumplings, grilled chicken skewers, or crispy spring rolls. For a refreshing beverage, consider serving it with green tea or a light lager beer, which complements the umami flavors of the soup without overpowering it.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Egg Drop Soup hot in a traditional Chinese soup bowl for an authentic experience. Garnish with additional sliced green onions or a sprinkle of sesame oil for enhanced flavor. You could also serve with a side of jasmine rice or a small salad with sesame dressing for a complete meal.

#

Egg Drop Soup

15 min
$5
80 kcal
Difficulty: 10%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

Eggs

Dietary Tags:

Gluten-FreeLow-Calorie

Cuisine:

Chinese

Course:

AppetizerMain Course

Tags:

QuickEasyComfort Food

Occasions:

Weeknight DinnerQuick Lunch

Description

A warm and comforting soup with silky eggs and green onions, perfect for a quick meal.

Ingredients

  • chicken broth: 4 cups
  • cornstarch: 1 tablespoon
  • water: 2 tablespoons
  • eggs: 2
  • green onions: 2, sliced
  • soy sauce: 1 tablespoon
  • salt: to taste
  • pepper: to taste

Date Created:

12/27/2024
